Problem:
Consider a stochastic differential equation given by \\(dX_t = \mu X_t dt + \sigma X_t dW_t\\) where \\(W_t\\) is a standard Brownian motion, \\(\mu\\) is the drift coefficient, and \\(\sigma\\) is the volatility coefficient. We explore the effect of a transformation described by \\( Z_t = e^{\lambda t}X_t \\) for some constant \\(\lambda\\).

If at some time \\( t_1 \\), a modification to the drift coefficient from \\(\mu\\) to \\(\mu'\\) is introduced as an intervention, will the subsequent path of \\( Z_t \\) for t > t_1 depend only on the new \\(\mu'\\) and not on the initial transformation constant \\(\lambda\\)?
Explanation: The path of \\( Z_t \\) for t > t_1 will depend both on the new \\(\mu'\\) and the constant \\(\lambda\\). The scaling \\( e^{\lambda t} \\) continues to influence the trajectory alongside the modified dynamics introduced by the new drift coefficient \\(\mu'\\).
